newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia to review foreign labour policy.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia to review foreign labour policy.

text.p: Malaysia will review its overseas labour recruitment policy after receiving complaints that foreign workers were involved in violence and causing social distrubances, local newspapers reported on Sunday.
Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim was quoted as saying on Saturday that the government had received numerous complaints about foreign workers from the public.
"We will look into it (policy) now," Anwar, who is also chairman of the Cabinet Committee on Foreign Workers, was quoted as saying The Sun.
"We have received several complaints and objections on their employment. That is why we are studying the matter so that we can come up with solutions," he was quoted as saying by the Star.
Foreign workers, especially Bangladeshis, have recently been involved in various fights with the local population.
Last Wednesday, a local man was assaulted by 13 Bangladeshis when he warned them against disturbing his sister.
Two days earlier, a factory security guard was beaten up by a group of Bangladeshi workers when he tried to stop one of them from bringing a friend into the factory hostel.

The worst incident took place on September 10 when seven Bangladeshi workers were seriously injured in a fight involving 70 Bangladeshis and residents of a village in southern Johor state. The cause of the fight was not known.
Booming Malaysia has more than 1.2 million foreign workers out of a total workforce of around eight million.
